List
Fiction
THE RESCUE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $22.95.) A volunteer fireman helps a young single mother search for her missing son, a 4-year-old with severe learning disabilities.
DROWNING RUTH, by Christina Schwarz. (Doubleday, $23.95.) In 1919, after the mysterious death of her sister, a Wisconsin woman takes control of the family farm and her niece.
THE BEAR AND THE DRAGON, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $28.95.) Aided by the antiterrorism specialist John Clark, President Jack Ryan contends with sinister forces afoot in Russia and China.
THE SKY IS FALLING, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $26.) A young anchorwoman investigates five seemingly accidental deaths that have befallen America's most charismatic family.
OPEN HOUSE, by Elizabeth Berg. (Random House, $23.95.) A newly divorced woman attempts to rebuild her life by taking in a series of boarders.
THE DEVIL'S CODE, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) A computer genius named Kidd probes the death of a colleague.
THE SWITCH, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $25.95.) A woman serving as a legendary astronaut's media escort searches for her identical twin sister's killer.
PERISH TWICE, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $23.95.) The Boston private eye Sunny Randall is hired by a prominent feminist who has received threatening phone calls.
SHATTERED, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $25.95.) A glass blower runs afoul of dangerous people after his jockey friend dies from a fall in a steeplechase.

THE BLIND ASSASSIN, by Margaret Atwood. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) The story of two Canadian sisters, one of whom dies in a car crash and leaves behind a science fiction novel that achieves cult status.
DUNE: House Harkonnen, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson. (Bantam, $27.50.) A prequel to the ''Dune'' chronicles, Frank Herbert's science fiction series.
TEMPTATION, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $24.95.) In 1909, a women's rights activist falls in love with a rough-mannered Scotsman.
WINTER SOLSTICE, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) As Christmas approaches, five lost souls in the north of Scotland discover the healing power of love.
A KISS OF SHADOWS, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Ballantine, $22.95.) The adventures of Merry Gentry, a private investigator with supernatural powers.
FOUR BLONDES, by Candace Bushnell. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The love lives of glamorous Manhattan women as seen by the author of ''Sex and the City.''

List
Nonfiction
THE BEATLES ANTHOLOGY, by the Beatles. (Chronicle, $60.) A profusely illustrated volume in which John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr tell their own story.
ON WRITING, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $25.) The novelist looks back on his career and offers guidance for would-be authors.
NOTHING LIKE IT IN THE WORLD, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) The story of the men who built the transcontinental railroad in the 1860's.
THE O'REILLY FACTOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $23.) The host of a cable news program offers opinions on what's right and wrong with America.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author, a sportswriter, tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
NATURAL BLONDE, by Liz Smith. (Hyperion, $25.95.) From Fort Worth to New York City: the memoir of a gossip columnist.
SELLOUT, by David P. Schippers with Alan P. Henry. (Regnery, $27.95.) The former chief Republican counsel for the House Judiciary Committee presents an account of President Clinton's impeachment. (+)
*DRUDGE MANIFESTO, by Matt Drudge with Julia Phillips. (New American Library, $22.95.) The publisher of the Drudge Report discusses his coverage of the Lewinsky scandal and the future of journalism.
I LOVE YOU, RONNIE, by Nancy Reagan. (Random House, $24.95.) Ronald Reagan's letters to his wife, along with her reflections on them.
CHERRY, by Mary Karr. (Viking, $24.95.) The sequel to ''The Liars' Club'' recounts the author's teenage years and her sexual coming of age.
LIFE ON THE OTHER SIDE, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Dutton, $23.95.) A guided tour of the afterlife, by a ''working psychic.''
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.
WHO WANTS TO BE ME? by Regis Philbin with Bill Zehme. (Hyperion, $22.95.) Anecdotes, opinions and confessions from the host of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and ''Live With Regis.''
*THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.

Children's Picture Books
WHERE DO BALLOONS GO? by Jamie Lee Curtis. Illustrated by Laura Cornell. (Cotler/HarperCollins, $16.95.) The adventures of a balloon after a little boy accidentally lets go of it. (Ages 4 to 8)
OLIVIA, written and illustrated by Ian Falconer. (Schwartz/Atheneum, $16.) A day (or two) in the life of a busy little pig. (Ages 3 to 7)
DREAM SNOW, written and illustrated by Eric Carle. (Philomel, $21.99.) After dreaming of snow, a farmer awakes to find that it really has snowed. (Ages 3 to 6)
WEMBERLY WORRIED, written and illustrated by Kevin Henkes. (Greenwillow, $15.95.) A mouse fears her first day of school. (Ages 4 to 8)
ANGELINA'S HALLOWEEN, by Katharine Holabird. Illustrated by Helen Craig. (Pleasant, $9.95.) A mouse goes trick-or-treating. (Ages 3 and up)
SO YOU WANT TO BE PRESIDENT? by Judith St. George. Illustrated by David Small. (Philomel, $17.99.) Anecdotes about the men who have occupied the White House. (Ages 9 to 12)
IF YOU TAKE A MOUSE TO THE MOVIES, by Laura Numeroff. Illustrated by Felicia Bond. (Geringer/ HarperCollins, $15.95.) Holiday antics. (Ages 3 to 7)
CRICKWING, written and illustrated by Janell Cannon. (Harcourt, $16.) A cockroach who is also a sculptor angers the queen of the ants. (Ages 6 to 9)
MOUSE'S FIRST HALLOWEEN, by Lauren Thompson. Illustrated by Buket Erdogan. (Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) The tale of a spooky night. (Ages 2 to 6)
I LOVE YOU LIKE CRAZY CAKES, by Rose Lewis. Illustrated by Jane Dyer. (Little, Brown, $14.95.) A woman travels to China to adopt a baby girl. (Ages 2 and up)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Oct. 7, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books. Best-seller lists for children's picture books, children's chapter books and children's paperbacks, respectively, are published in rotation on succeeding weeks; all three lists appear each week on the Book Review's Web site. Publishers have provided the age designations for their best-selling children's titles. Rankings for children's paperbacks do not include serials.
